Award.AwardTitle: EAR-PF Late Quaternary slip rates and paleoseismicity of the Sevier Desert Detachment: earthquake hazards of a low-angle normal fault
Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Timothy Stahl has been awarded an NSF EAR Postdoctoral Fellowship to conduct a research and field-based education program through the University of Michigan. He will investigate the paleoseismicity and seismogenic potential of the Sevier Desert Detachment (SDD)- a low-angle normal fault (LANF) in central Utah. This project aims to (1) establish the long-term slip rates of the SDD; (2) determine the timing and magnitude of past earthquakes on the SDD; (3) model the probability of multi-segment or multi-fault ruptures on the SDD and faults soling into it at depth. Dr. Stahl will use a combination of field mapping, terrestrial laser scanning, cosmogenic surface exposure-age dating, paleoseismic trenching, and numerical modeling to meet the above research aims.

This is the first study to examine field evidence for the timing and magnitude of prehistoric earthquakes on a LANF. The research will elucidate the controversial and potentially devastating seismic hazard posed by these faults in the US and worldwide. The fellowship supports the development of field-based, collaborative research projects for undergraduates at the U. Michigan and Snow College, a two-year undergraduate college in central Utah. Dr. Stahl will also lead a one-month field camp for U. Michigan students in New Zealand, the host country of his PhD studies, aimed at broadening knowledge of different tectonic settings around the world and establishing international connections between USA and New Zealand undergraduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research investigated the earthquake hazards and paleoseismicity of active faults in the Sevier Desert of Utah. One of the central research questions was whether active faults identified at the Earth’s surface are related to and/or rupture together with the Sevier Desert Detachment—a controversial structure that has been imaged in seismic reflection studies and debated for nearly four decades.

The overarching purpose of this work was to use the characteristics of faults at the surface to (i) refine the likely maximum earthquake magnitudes and recurrence intervals of future seismic events in the Sevier Desert region and (ii) elucidate how the Earth extends at the eastern margin of the Basin and Range and at the southern termination of the Wasatch Fault Zone. In doing so, three undergraduate research projects in 3D surveying and visualization of tectonically active landscapes were completed and a month-long fieldtrip focused on New Zealand’s active tectonic plate boundary was developed and led for University of Michigan students.

Multiple techniques were employed to investigate active faults in the region (Stahl and Niemi, 2017). Terrestrial laser scans (conducted with UNAVCO) and UAV-photogrammetry (conducted by Utah Valley University) provided detailed glimpses of how and when Pleistocene shorelines of Lake Bonneville were displaced by faults. New mapping, paleoseismic trenching, and RTK GPS surveys, conducted in conjunction with the Utah Geological Survey, were used to map and measure the amounts of displacement across ~10 km wide, complex zones of faulting. Continuous GPS was used to model the rates of extension on the Wasatch Fault and to test the hypothesis that the Sevier Desert Detachment is actively slipping. Stahl and Niemi (2017) concluded that the Sevier Desert Detachment is unlikely to be currently active and that magmatism plays a role in accommodating extension in the Sevier Desert. The results of extensive geochronology and exposure-age dating greatly revise the timing of volcanic and seismic events in the Sevier Desert. Earthquake magnitudes are unlikely to exceed Magnitude ~6 on faults in the eastern study area (see attached image). 

This fellowship facilitated early-career training for PI Stahl, his inclusion in NSF’s Geotechnical Extreme Event Reconnaissance (GEER) for the 2016 Kaikoura (New Zealand) earthquake, and produced an invited essay in AGU’s 2017 March for Science / Earth Day Commentaries. The research findings are being disseminated in conference proceedings, invited talks, and peer-reviewed publications. The PI developed and led a successful international field trip stemming from his post-doctoral research, providing valuable experience for teaching future field classes and college courses.
